poem_title: THE IMPERTINENT, OR A Visit to the COURT. A SATYR.
author: Alexander Pope

lines.line_text: WELL, if it be my time to quit the Stage,
Adieu to all the Follies of the Age!
I die in Charity with Fool and Knave,
Secure of Happiness beyond the Grave.
I've had my  here betimes,
And paid for all my Satires, all my Rhymes:
The Poet's Hell, its Tortures, Fiends and Flames,
To this were Trifles, Toys, and empty Names.

stanzas.stanza_text:
WELL, if it be my time to quit the Stage,
Adieu to all the Follies of the Age!
I die in Charity with Fool and Knave,
Secure of Happiness beyond the Grave.
I've had my  here betimes,
And paid for all my Satires, all my Rhymes:
The Poet's Hell, its Tortures, Fiends and Flames,
To this were Trifles, Toys, and empty Names.

lines.line_text: With foolish  my Heart was never fir'd,
Nor the vain Itch  or
I hop'd for no  from his Grace;
I bought no  I begg'd no
Had no  or  to show;
Yet went to COURT! — the Dev'l wou'd have it so.
But, as the Fool, that in reforming Days
Wou'd go to Mass in jest, (as Story says)
Could not but think, to pay his  was odd,
Since 'twas no form'd Design of serving God:
Such was my Fate; whom Heav'n adjudg'd as
As prone to  as negligent of
As deep in  without a thought to pay,
As  as  and as  as they
Who  at  for going once that Way!

lines.line_text: Scarce was I enter'd, when behold! there came
A Thing which  had been pos'd to name;
had refus'd it lodging in his Ark,
Where all the Race of  might embark:
A verier Monster than on  Shore
The Sun e're got, or slimy  bore,
Or  or  wondrous. Shelves contain;
Nay, all that lying Travellers can feign.

stanzas.stanza_text:
Scarce was I enter'd, when behold! there came
A Thing which  had been pos'd to name;
had refus'd it lodging in his Ark,
Where all the Race of  might embark:
A verier Monster than on  Shore
The Sun e're got, or slimy  bore,
Or  or  wondrous. Shelves contain;
Nay, all that lying Travellers can feign.

lines.line_text: This Thing has  speaks each Language too,
And knows what's fit for ev'ry State to do;
Of whose best Phrase and courtly Accent join'd,
He forms one Tongue exotic and refin'd.
Talkers, I've learn'd to bear;  I knew,
himself I've heard, nay  too:
The Doctor's Wormwood Style, the Hash of Tongues,
A Pedant makes; the Storm of  Lungs,
The whole Artill'ry of the Terms of War,
And (all those Plagues in one) the bawling Bar;
These I cou'd bear; but not a Rogue so civil,
Whose Tongue can complement you to the Devil.
A Tongue that can cheat Widows, cancel Scores,
Make  speak Treason, cozen subtlest Whores,
With Royal Favourites in Flatt'ry vie,
And  and  both out-lie.

lines.line_text: He spies me out. I whisper, gracious God!
What Sin of mine cou'd merit such a Rod?
That all the Shot of Dulness now must be
From this thy Blunderbuss discharg'd on me!
Well met (he cries) and happy sure for each,
For I am pleas'd to learn, and you to teach;
What  esteem you most? — "The , said I,
But the best  —"O Sir, the
You miss my aim; I mean the most acute
And perfect  past dispute.
But Sir, of Writers? —" for closer Style,
"And  for a Period of a Mile.
Why yes, 'tis granted, these indeed may pass;
Good common Linguists, and so  was:
Nay troth, th'  (tho' perhaps too rough)
Had once a pretty Gift of Tongues enough.
Yet these were all I dare
Affirm, 'twas  made them what they were.

lines.line_text: Thus others Talents having nicely shown,
He came by soft Transition to his own:
Till I cry'd out, You prove yourself so able,
Pity! you was not Druggerman at
For had they found a Linguist half so good,
I make no question but the  had stood.

lines.line_text: "Obliging Sir! I love you, I profess,
"But wish you lik'd Retreat a little less;
"Spirits like you, believe me, shou'd be seen,
"And (like  visit Courts, and Men.
"So much  (to speak plain Truth between us)
"You'll die of Spleen — Excuse me,
But as for  forgive me if I say,
No Lessons now are taught the  way:
Tho' in his Pictures Lust be full display'd,
Few are the Converts  has made;
And tho' the Court show  exceeding clear,
None shou'd, by my Advice, learn  there.

lines.line_text: At this, entranc'd, he lifts his Hands and Eyes,
Squeaks like a high-stretch'd Lutestring, and replies:
"Oh 'tis the sweetest of all earthly things
"To gaze on Princes, and to talk of Kings! "
Then happy Man who shows the Tombs! said I,
He dwells amidst the Royal Family;
He, ev'ry Day, from  to  can walk,
Of all our  all our  talk,
And get by speaking Truth of Monarchs dead,
What few can of the living,  and
"Lord! Sir, a meer  strangely low,
"And coarse of Phrase — your  all are so.
"How elegant your  — Mine, d'ye mean?
I have but one, I hope the Fellow's clean.
"Oh! Sir, politely well! nay, let me dye,
"Your only wearing is your
Not Sir, my only — I have better still,
And this, you see, is but my Dishabille —
Wild to get loose, his Patience I provoke,
Mistake, confound, object, at all he spoke.
But as coarse Iron, sharpen'd, mangles more,
And Itch most hurts, when anger'd to a Sore;
So when you plague a Fool, 'tis still the Curse,
You only make the Matter worse and worse.

lines.line_text: He past it o'er; put on an easy Smile
At all my Peevishness, and chang'd his Style.
He asks, What I tell him of new Plays.
New Eunuchs, Harlequins, and Operas.
He hears; and as a Still, with Simples in it,
Between each Drop it gives, stays half a Minute;
Loth to enrich me with too quick Replies
By little, and by little, drops his Lies.
Meer  of Birth-Nights, Balls and Shows,
More than ten  or  or
When the  frown'd, or smil'd, he knows; and what
A subtle Minister may make of that?
Who sins with whom? who got his Pension
Or quicken'd a Reversion by a
Whose Place is  three Parts in four,
And whether to a Bishop, or a Whore?
Who, having lost his Credit, pawn'd his Rent,
Is therefore fit to have a
Who in the  deals in Stocks secure,
And cheats th'unknowing Widow, and the Poor?
Who makes a  or  a Job,
And gets an Ac of Parliament to rob?
Why  rose, and why no Cit, nor Clown
Can  see the  or the
Shortly no Lad shall  or Lady
But some excising Courtier will have Toll.
He tells what Strumpet Places sells for Life,
What 'Squire his Lands, what Citizen his Wife?
And last (which proves him wiser still than all)
What Lady's Face is not a whited Wall?
As one of  Patients, sick and sore,
I puke, I nauseate, — yet he thrusts in more;
Shows  Int'rests, takes the  part,
And talks  and  o'er by heart.
Like a big Wife at sight of loathsome Meat,
Ready to cast, I yawn, I sigh, I sweat:
Then as a licens'd Spy, whom nothing can
Silence, or hurt, he libels the
Swears every  for Years to come,
In  to the Day of Doom:
He names the  for ev'ry  paid,
And says our  because
Nay hints, 'tis by Connivance of the Court,
That  robs on, and  still a Port.
Not more Amazement seiz'd on  Guests,
To see themselves fall endlong into Beasts,
Than mine, to find a Subject staid and wise,
Already half turn'd Traytor by surprize.
I felt th'Infection slide from him to me,
As in the Pox, some give it, to get free;
And quick to swallow me, methought I saw
One of our Giant  ope its Jaw!
In that nice Moment, as another Lye
Stood just a-tilt, the  came by.
Away he flies. He bows, and bows again;
And close as  joins the dirty Train.
Not  self more impudently near,
When half his Nose is in his Patron's Ear.
I blest my Stars! but still afraid to see
All the Court fill'd with stranger things than he,
Run out as fast, as one that pays his Bail
And dreads more Actions, hurries from a Jail.

lines.line_text: Bear me, some God! oh quickly bear me hence
To wholesome Solitude, the Nurse of Sense:
Here Contemplation prunes her ruffled Wings,
And the free Soul looks down to pity Kings.
Here still Reflection led on sober Thought,
Which Fancy colour'd, and a Vision wrought.
A  Hermits can to Hell transport,
And bring ev'n me to see the Damn'd at Court.
Not  dreaming all th'Infernal State,
Saw such a Scene of  and
Base Fear becomes the Guilty, not the Free;
Suits Tyrants, Plunderers, but suits not me.
Shall I, the Terror of this sinful Town,
Care, if a livery'd Lord or smile or frown?
Who cannot flatter, and detest who can,
Tremble before a
O my fair Mistress, Shall I quit thee,
For huffing, braggart, puft
Thou, who since Yesterday, hast roll'd o'er all
The busy, idle Blockheads of the Ball,
Hast thou,  beheld an emptier sort,
Than such as swell this Bladder of a Court?
Now pox on those who shew a
It ought to bring all Courtiers on their backs.
Such painted Puppets, such a varnish'd Race
Of hollow Gewgaws, only Dress and Face,
Such waxen Noses, stately, staring things,
No wonder some Folks bow, and think them

To wholesome Solitude, the Nurse of Sense:

At  or , with  or a
Pay their last Duty to the  and come
All fresh and fragrant, to the
Colours as gay, and Odours as divine,
As the fair Fields they sold to look so fine.

For these are Actors too, as well as those:
Wants reach all States; they beg but better drest,
And all is  at best.

lines.line_text: Painted for sight, and essenc'd for the smell,
Like Frigates fraught with Spice and Cochine'l,
Sail in the  How each Pyrate eyes
So weak a Vessel, and so rich a Prize!
Top-gallant he, and she in all her Trim,
He boarding her, she striking sail to him.
" you have Charms all Hearts to hit!"
And " you have so much wit!"
Such Wits and Beauties are not prais'd for nought,
For both the Beauty and the Wit are
'Twou'd burst ev'n  with the Spleen.
To see those Anticks,  and
The  seems, with things so richly odd,
The Mosque of  or some queer
See them survey their Limbs by  Rules,
Of all Beau-kind the best proportion'd Fools!
Adjust their Cloaths, and to Confession draw
Each idle Atom, or erroneous Straw;
What Terrors wou'd distract each conscious Soul,
Convicted of that mortal Sin, a Hole!
Or should one Pound of Powder less bespread
The Monkey-Tail that wags behind his Head!
Thus finish'd and corrected to a hair,
They march, to prate their Hour before the Fair,
So first to preach a white-glov'd Chaplain goes,
With Band of Lily, and with Cheek of Rose,
Sweeter than  in immaculate trim,
Neatness itself impertinent in him.
Let but the Ladies smile, and they are blest;
Prodigious! how the Things
Peace, Fools! or  will for Papists seize you,
If once he catch you at your

lines.line_text: Nature made ev'ry Fop to plague his Brother,
Just as one Beauty mortifies another.
But here's the  that will plague you both,
Whose Air cries Arm! whose very Look's an Oath:
What tho' his Soul be Bullet, Body Buff?
Damn him, he's honest, Sir, — and that's enuff.
He spits fore-right; his haughty Chest before,
Like batt'ring Rams, beats open ev'ry Door;
And with a Face as red, and as awry,
As  Hang-dogs in old Tapestry,
Scarecrow to Boys, the breeding Woman's curse;
Has yet a strange Ambition to
Confounds the Civil, keeps the Rude in awe,
Jests like alicens'd Fool, commands like Law.
Frighted, I quit the Room, but leave it so,
As Men from Jayls to Execution go;
For hung with  I see the Wall,
And lin'd with  deadlier than 'em all:
Each Man an  of strength to toss
For Quoits, both  and
Scar'd at the grizly Forms, I sweat, I fly,
And shake all o'er, like a discover'd Spy.
are no match for Wits so weak as mine;
Charge them with Heav'n's Artill'ry, bold
From such alone the Great Rebukes endure,
Whose   and whose Rage
'Tis mine to wash a few slight Stains; but theirs
To deluge Sin, and drown a Court in Tears.
Howe'er, what's now  my Wit,
In time to come, may pass for
